text: in this talk I will describe how crowdsourcing can be used in personal information
management crowd sourcing has been able to do some pretty amazing things and I will start with some examples gton in
1907 that's about a 100 years ago went to a farmer fair where 800 farmers
competed to guess the guess the the to guess the weight of an ox and not a
single one guessed it right but what's impressive is that the average of all
guesses were was only one pound away from the exact weight
this is an example of the wisdom of the crowd where independence of many estimates can provide results that no
individual can over the last decade crowd sourcing patterns have uh uh created much more
complex um ways to chain these estimates together to be able to solve even more
challenging tasks for example this totally illeible text was deciphered by online workers using iterative
refinement researchers have even created plugins for Microsoft Word to provide
crowdpowered grammar checking and summarization of text and with things like Wikipedia
people coordinate at a scale accuracy and keep it up to date in a way that is
that no centralized organization has been able to do in the past research has shown that remote online
workers can be organized in such ways to provide metadata structure and to
identify important information when needed for example in a project that was helping blind people um the blind people
were able to take pictures of items they were interested to read and the crowd was able to read the labels of those
items back to them now that we've seen some of the achievements of crowd sourcing can crowd
sourcing help us help us manage our personal information for example email overload
and task management in this thesis I apply crowdsourcing to email overload
and task management people are overloaded on both aspects because
management requires planning decision making and it consumes willpower so people tend to postpone
this planning and as a result they miss deadlines or they fail to uh complete
goals and expectations and there's big unsolved problems in the existing literature how
to effectively apply crowd sourcing in personal information management and if you if you do that how to address
privacy and accountability concerns for private user data in this dissertation I'm
introducing the genius pattern for organizing and scaling crowdsourced work
the valet pattern for addressing privacy and accountability concerns and I instantiate those two patterns in in a
couple of systems email valet and task genius i'm also using these systems to
uh show experimental evidence that uh external this external organization is helpful to people and that crowd
sourcing is an effective way to pro to provide it email valet is an email client that automatically extract tasks
from people's uh inboxes and task genius is an is a to-do list program that
provides action plans to to tasks so that people can complete them uh more easily
i will start with email valet the valet crowd sourcing approach and behavioral
findings from these uh two then I will talk about task genius the genius
pattern and the related findings we want to extend crowd
sourcing such that people feel comfortable sharing personal information with assistants and to do that I'm going
to introduce the idea of valet crowd sourcing a valet key for a car is a key
that can give access to a driver only to to open the door or maybe
start the engine but it doesn't let them uh access the trunk or the glove compartment of the car so this key is
effectively giving two guarantees one is that it limits functionality the driver can't get into your trunk but it also
establishes accountability so the the driver is responsible for the car car while they have the key but not before
or after and this is a really nice interface actually because it's simple and clear to
everyone similarly val crowd sourcing parimoniously gives assistants just
enough access to to do most of the work without giving them access to all user data
second it seeks act to establish accountability by making access
boundaries transparent and by designing access logs so that transgressions are recorded and the crowd workers are held
responsible for their actions to understand what led us to valet crowd sourcing let's look at email
overload prior research has found that people
spend a lot of time to transform their overwhelming inboxes to actions they need to take in this uh inbox the
important tasks are just in these few emails it would be nice if I could see
only those five emails and even better if I could see the actual tasks because that would give me time to it would save
me time to that I have to reread and remember uh what the tasks are in those
emails for example there's a there's an email there with a subject will be full soon and that really means that I need
to buy a new hard drive for the
server but would you feel comfortable giving crowd workers access to your
inbox to extract those tasks for you well we surveyed 500 US residents
and less than 4% of them was willing to share they were worried about privacy and accountability one uh uh informant
said "I'd want some liability insurance for what a rogue assistant might do with my information." So Valet crowdsourcing is
trying to address exactly these problems and we created email valet as an instantiation of this gmail valet.com it's the first is
the first application of email valet it's an email client that uh gives access to the same emails that you have
in Gmail but it has two interfaces one interface is for users where they can see everything and they can perform the
the usual uh actions that you do with your email and another interface is the interface for assistants and in that
interface you get access to only a limited subset of your inbox they the assistants can perform
only a limited subset of the actions based on the user's preferences and all
actions of assistants are recorded also email valet has a task
list interface uh it incorporates that right into your inbox so the assistants extract tasks for you and uh you can
accept or decline uh those extractions and you can add any missing tasks to
build better common ground we when when a when a user declines a task then uh uh
they can the system offers them offers him the ability to leave a note so that they can tell the reason why they cl
they declined the task here we see a user reading
emails and extracting
tasks and clicking on the various tasks to see which uh emails they're coming
from so for privacy assistants have no access to user
passwords they cannot search old emails in fact they can only see the
last x emails for from uh uh a person's inbox where x could be 100 for example
to for for further uh peace of mind users can restrict access to only emails
that are in priority inbox or that have stars or that emails that they have sent
to themselves and uh they could even uh restrict it to emails that have a
special label assistant possibly using uh Gmail filters uh to uh select
those and for further peace of mind the there's a there there there's there are
block there's specific uh there there's a specific option where the users can uh
uh specify block keywords for example an email address or a name or a domain name
uh and emails that contain those keyboard keywords are always invisible by the assistants for example someone
can put the name of his girlfriend or the bank account name and uh they know that even if those emails were uh would
be visible due to the other uh rules they wouldn't be visible because of the
of this feature finally for a special block keyword is default to everyone and
this prevents from somebody else's assistant see a private message that
you're sending to them you can include that keyword and you know that it is in his block
list users decide what uh assistant act what actions the assistants can take for
example they decide whether the assistant can archive delete reply or
start messages and whether they can manage tasks for
transparency emails are visible emails that are visible to assistants are clearly marked from on the inbox and
assistant actions are always recorded here's a screenshot with uh one email
selected we can see those preview icons on the inbox directly so messages that
are visible to assistants have a human icon and messages that are not visible
to assistants have a lock icon hovering over the these icons reveals
the reason why the system uh made uh this uh visibility choice and by
clicking on the icon itself it overrides that assistant actions are also
displayed here an assistant has extracted a couple of tasks for one of the emails
a record of all actions is visible along with the message details right here and
in a separate view you can see the complete log
file in a controlled experiment we tested whether email valet helps people
complete email-based tasks and how people adopted valet
sharing it was a within subjects design with 28 participants they were assisted
by three crowd odesk workers the study had three conditions counterbalanced in
a Latin square manner so the conditions were control self and valet to describe the conditions I will
say that the assistants extracted tasks for all participants for all conditions
but these tasks were hidden from the participants during the control and self phases in the control condition people
uh just used email in the traditional way in the self condition they were encouraged to extract their own tasks
out of emails and in the valet condition they received the full the full email valet
assistance the measures in this study were assistant accuracy and completion rate we gathered this by asking
participants at the end of each condition to correct the task extractions that were made by the
assistants and to mark all completed tasks the study concluded with a survey
to explore reactions to valet crowd sourcing let's look at some of the
results first participants completed twice as many tasks in the valet condition
compared to the other two also the assistant task extraction accuracy
improved over time from 65% up to 85% at the end of the study and the cost of the
system was relatively inexpensive uh it cost about $2 a day per user even at an
$8 per hour wage for the assistance but how do people react to valet crowd
sourcing well we expected they would be very reserved in sharing but we found
out that nearly everyone shared at least some part of their inbox with automatic val filters in fact only two
participants handpicked messages to show to the assistants at the end only three
people said that they would stop using uh email valet for privacy reasons the
majority of participants 18 uh initially felt uncomfortable uh with uh with
sharing but 11 of them reported that they were feeling more comfortable over time and that finding is really
reinforcing the belief that privacy is a dynamic dialectic process when the
benefit exceeds the invasion people are willing to share information they previously considered private one
participant said "Originally I did not share emails from my boyfriend but I changed that after realizing he sent me
emails with tasks for me to do." Another one said "Uh my uneasiness
reduced over time as I was impressed with the accuracy of correct tasks generated for
me." Assistants also shared some discomfort one assistant said "Some
emails I felt like I was invading their privacy because I it was emails between my clients and their family but I didn't
react anyway because it's a job I have to do." As we saw email valet has plenty of
elements to support accountability however these were not the most frequently used features of the system
but the mere fact that they exist increased comfort for the users and adoption for the for the
system to recap I presented a first use of crowdsourced expert assistance to
support personal information management valet crowd sourcing that seeks to balance privacy and accountability for
sensitive data the email valet system for email task management and empirical
results that crowd assistants can manage information
accurately email valet extracts tasks from inboxes but how do people complete
their tasks and how can the crowd help them complete more tasks that's exactly what task genius is
studying a major issue with task execution is
that highlevel tasks are not actionable and people delay doing them michael
Slackeneri from PhD comics has a a to-do list that contains a bunch of concrete
tasks and one highle task work on thesis as time goes by he completes all of his
concrete tasks but his highle task lingers in the end he declares bankruptcy and creates a new task list
that contains still that lingering high level
task researchers studied the importance of forming action plans through another
experiment as well they talked to students to university students about the benefits of a flu shot but they
divided the students into two classrooms in one room they just talked about the benefits in the other room they also
talked about asked them to create to form action plans on how they're going to get that shot and they found that
students in that room got the shot more frequently so just to be clear an action
plan is simply a list of steps to complete a task for example in the task exercise frequently and act a possible
action plan can be get a gym membership create a weekly exercise schedule and find a workout body to keep you
accountable let's look at some of the benefits of
creating action plans as we saw people get more efficient with
smaller steps to act on also completing those intermediate
steps is rewarding and it's easier to make
smaller decisions on how to proceed when you have smaller steps to to do
finally people are more productive when they are interrupted between steps than
uh during steps so having those action plans
provides a good in interruption moment it's the time you mark off a small task
on your list however planning takes time right
away whereas the benefits of planning come later so people often ta fail to
plan can technology help provide those plans automatically and if that's possible do
those plans help or is it the act of contemplating the the plans yourself
that provides the benefit here's a sketch of completion
rate against convenience not creating uh action plans is
convenient because you don't have to do it but it's less productive as we saw and creating action plans is is more
productive but it's inconvenient because you have to create them uh could we combine the benefits from both with
automatically provided action plans and that's the main hypothesis of
task genius that yes providing action plans helps people complete tasks and
that crowdsourcing is an effective way to do it
plans exist for some domains for example recipes instructibles e-how and you can
even search or create your own but all that takes time and effort and that's exactly what we want to avoid
here task Genius is a to-do list that automatically decomposes people's tasks
to action plans on the left you can enter tasks and subtasks like a like a
tree and on the right you see action plan recommendations automatically
generated for you we do that using uh Amazon
Mechanical Tech workers to create the action plans and NLP uh techniques to

Turk is a community of about 200,000 online workers who execute chunks of

in our case for creating action plans here is a preview of uh the crowd sourcing interface of Task Genius but I
will and I will talk more about it a bit later to create action plans we tried using
three simple crowdsourcing patterns and we found problems so we created a fourth pattern the genius pattern to address
these problems let's look at these patterns one at a time we started with a parallel pattern
in the parallel pattern all workers ask were asked to independently create action plans and in the end uh the they
picked they rated and they picked the best the results
[Music] were the results as as in many as in
many cases in we see in Amazon Mechanical Turk there was a lot of spam or low quality in independent uh uh

were um providing solutions to the wrong problem and here's an example of uh that
uh for the task uh read the rest of the hidden reality which is a book one worker broke it down into its
words and another tried to execute the task no matter what no matter what we changed
in the description of the that we provided that didn't help we we realized
that the more text we add the the worse the results u are the less people read
it probably uh in the serial approach the first worker creates a plan the
second worker improves that plan based uh on the improves the plan of the first
worker and the third worker continues on the second worker's work and so on and so forth this creates multiple versions
and the best one is selected in the end well in this uh pattern we we still
didn't see much improvement in quality and we even further saw a new problem which was fixation to early ideas
sometimes uh uh a the first worker would provide a bad idea and then everyone
would just improve on that uh here's an example um for the same task read the
rest of the hidden reality the first worker created read chapter one to three read chapter four to six and so on and
so forth and then following workers improved it to read chapter one chapter
two so to combine the benefits from both approaches we created a a revising
approach which in the beginning it asked workers to independently like in the parallel approach create uh their their
action plans after they created an action plan the the workers were displayed all the versions of other
action plans created by other workers and then to they were asked to revise their own if they if they wanted in the
end the best was uh selected with rating um this uh
technique actually gave us better quality and we saw that good ideas
propagated but they actually propagated slowly because uh probably because people had already completed their work
when they were asked to look at examples and they rarely revised their own work
it was already done um so it was still a wasteful and expensive uh way to produce
the plants to solve all these problems we created the genius pattern that uh is
composed of uh three phases rate contemplate and synthesize and I will explain those right
away so we still need ratings to determine the best solutions and instead
of uh putting these ratings at the end of the work of the worker we we put them at the beginning but to avoid fixation
to um to to fixation like in the serial
approach um we asked workers to rate action plans of different tasks than the one they were supposed to uh

solution but this rating also trains them and calibrates them on the quality
of uh that is expected it also demonstrates in the upfront that work
will be assessed and how it will be assessed and possibly this way dissuades some lazy workers from
continuing to encourage independent thinking we start uh workers start
creating their action plans for from a clean slate and only in the middle of producing their their own solution they

we tested exactly this hypothesis the experiment had 280 participants and we
